note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

James A. Green belonged to the following social groups:
Eli Abbott was a politician and planter in northeast Mississippi.

Born on July 6, 1801 in Georgia, Abbott served as a captain in the Seminole War in Florida (1835-1842). After the war, he lived in Columbus, Lowdnes County, Mississippi, where he was a planter and enslaver of at least thirty-three men, women, and children. From 1838 to 1839, he was the city mayor, and from 1842 to 1843, he served as the sheriff. In 1849, he donated land for the First Christian Church in Columbus, Mississippi, and in 1853, he purchased land in Chickasaw County and was elected as a state Representative.
During the Civil War Abbott joined the Mississippi militia and served as the captain of Abbott's Company, Mississippi Cavalry for Chickasaw County.
After the war, Abbott joined the board of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, and he moved to Egypt, Mississippi by 1870. He was working as a farmer.

Abbott was married to Clarissa "Clara" (Tapley) Abbott. The pair had two sons who lived to adulthood, but they also took in at least two nephews and possibly other orphaned children. Eli Abbott and his wife Clara died in 1879. They were buried in the Abbott Family Cemetery in Egypt, Chickasaw County, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; Southern Argus, November 6, 1838; Columbus Democrat, June 8, 1839; The Primitive Republican, April 27, 1843; The Weekly Mississippian, June 22, 1843; The Weekly Mississippian, November 25, 1853; The Clarion Ledger, April 26, 1866; 1840 United States Federal Census, Lowdnes County, Mississippi; U.S. Census Record for Lowdnes County, 1850; U.S., Civil War Soldiers, 1861-1865 ; U.S. Census Record for Chickasaw County, Mississippi, 1870)
Eli Abbott belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Chickasaw County, Egypt was founded in 1844 as Pikeville. Egypt is an unincorporated area that is not governed by a local municipal body. (Wikipedia)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)
The Territory of Tennessee was established in 1789 after breaking away from North Carolina. Admitted as the 16th state, Tennessee achieved statehood June 1, 1796. (Britannica)

gloss.p: "A system of transportation using special vehicles whose wheels turn on metal bars fixed to the ground, or a particular company using such a system." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Railroads and Railroad Companies--Mobile and Ohio Railroad Company (Mobile, Ala.)

gloss.p: Located in Mobile, Alabama, the Mobile and Ohio Railroad Company was a railroad company established in 1848 by Alabama, Kentucky, Mississippi, and Tennessee, and operated until 1940 when it merged with Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad. (Wikipedia)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person with special training in the medical field." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A medical doctor, especially one who has general skill and is not a surgeon." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A doctor who is specially trained to perform medical operations." (Cambridge Dictionary)

div.p:
Gov Jno J Pettus,
Jackson Missi

My Dear Sir. I write you in behalf of my friend Dr Jas H Green. This county, who wants a Situation in the Armey, as Surgeon—Dr Green is about 40 years of age, is active, Sober industrious, and attentive to his business can give you any Refferances that may be wanting, but permit me to Say, that he will do on any part of the ground: for I have tried him—The Dr is a Tennessian, & son of Judge Green, whom you may know—If I was Commander of a Regiment of Volunteers, there is no man that I would prefer to Dr Green—If you want his Survises write to him at this office Egypt, & tell him all about it & oblige

Dr Green
for surgeon
by E Abbott
